newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia ringgit falls sharply in volatile trade.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia ringgit falls sharply in volatile trade.

text.p: The Malaysian ringgit fell below the crucial 2.65 to a dollar barrier around 0133 GMT in volatile trade, dealers said on Thursday.
They said volumes were thin and spreads wide.
At 0137 GMT, the ringgit was at 2.6500/50 to a dollar against around 2.6370 an hour earlier.
"All regional currencies are falling this morning led by the Thai baht," said a market analyst with a Singapore-based research firm.

He said the selldown was triggered by an unconfirmed rumour that the Bank of Thailand was planning to lift restrictions on swaps, which have created a two-tier market, one domestic and other overseas.
"There does not seem much basis for the rumour," he said.
Dealers said no central bank of the region was present in the market. On Wednesday, Bank Negara was said to be in the market checking through some agent banks.
The currencies are widely expected to be left untouched by the authorities until a meeting of Asian central banks in Shanghai over the weekend.
"If no clear policy emerges from the central banks' meeting, Monday should again be a roller coaster ride," a dealer said.
The head of regional currencies at a European bank in Singapore said the Singapore dollar's sharp decline in the morning was responsible for sentiment around the region weakening.
"When a current account surplus country like Singapore can be hit so badly, where do other countries, which have huge deficits, stand," he said.
Dealers said dollar/ringgit was trading at a premium to the September futures contract on the New York Cotton Exchange (NYCE), which closed at 2.6450 on Wednesday.
